trans-unit.source: Inserted into a Web page as a placeholder when the attempt to load or create a new instance of a dynamic <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart"></xref> control has failed.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart> class is used by the Web Parts control set as a placeholder for a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control that could not be added to the page.

If the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartManager> control attempts to load or create a new instance of a dynamic <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control in a zone, and the attempt fails for some reason, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartManager> then calls the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartManager.CreateErrorWebPart%2A> method, and inserts an <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart> control in place of the control that failed.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart> control is inserted to preserve previously existing personalization state information that might have existed on a control for users.

For example, suppose there is a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control that has a personalizable property, so that users can save their own ZIP Code, and then the control can automatically display weather information for that ZIP Code each time the user visits the page.

If at some point a problem occurs with the weather control so that it cannot be loaded during a specific request, and yet the rest of the page does load successfully, the custom personalization data that a user has saved for that control would be lost the next time the personalization data for the page is saved.

By inserting the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart> control in place of the failed control, you can notify the user that a problem has occurred, and also provide a mechanism for the Web Parts control set to preserve the user's personalization data on the failed control until the problem can be corrected.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart> class derives from the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ProxyWebPart> class, as one of several types designed to be temporary placeholders for other types.
To create an instance of the class, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartManager> control uses its public <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart.%23ctor%2A> constructor.

The constructor requires several details of the failed control to be passed to it, such as the ID, the original type of the control (if the failed control is a server or user control wrapped in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.GenericWebPart> object), the original path to the source file for the control (if the failed control is a user control), and the ID of a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.GenericWebPart> object if present.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart> class has a single public property called <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart.ErrorMessage%2A>.
Developers can assign a value to this property that will be displayed in a Web page when the control is inserted.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart> class has three protected methods.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart.AddAttributesToRender%2A> method takes style characteristics from the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebZone.ErrorStyle%2A> object for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebZone> zone that contains the control that failed to load.
If any style settings exist in this object, the method applies them to the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart> control.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart.EndLoadPersonalization%2A> method sets several important inherited properties on the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart> control, to prevent users from personalizing the control by hiding, minimizing, editing, or exporting it, or changing its <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.Part.ChromeState%2A> value.

Finally, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart.RenderContents%2A> method encodes the value of the string in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart.ErrorMessage%2A> property, to prevent rendering problems or scripting attacks.
Initializes a new instance of the control.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartManager> control creates a new instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart> control when it fails in an attempt to load or create an instance of a dynamic <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control.

Dynamic controls are controls that are added to a page programmatically, or by a user who adds the control from a catalog of controls, as opposed to static controls that are declared in the markup of a Web page.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart.%23ctor%2A> method simply creates an instance of the base class, passing to it the four parameters that contain information about the failed control.
A string that is the control ID (not the unique ID) of the failing control.
If a <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.GenericWebPart"></xref> control is involved in the failure, the ID is the ID of its child server control.
A string that is the name of the <xref href="System.Type"></xref> of the failed control.
If a <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.GenericWebPart"></xref> control is involved in the failure, the type name is the type of its child server control.
A string that contains the path to a user control, if a <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.GenericWebPart"></xref> control that contains a child user control is involved in the failure.
A string that returns the ID of a <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.GenericWebPart"></xref> control, if that type of control was involved in the failure to load or create a control.
This is needed for controls that do not inherit from the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart"></xref> base class.
Applies special error style attributes to an <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart"></xref> object that is inserted into a page in place of another control.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart.AddAttributesToRender%2A> method takes the style characteristics (if any) that are defined in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebZone.ErrorStyle%2A> object for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebZone> zone that contains an <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart> control.
The styles are applied to the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart> control prior to rendering.
An <xref href="System.Web.UI.HtmlTextWriter"></xref> that contains the HTML output to be rendered.
Sets several important properties on the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart"></xref> control prior to rendering, to prevent users from being able to personalize the control.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart.EndLoadPersonalization%2A> method sets properties on an <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart> control before it is rendered.
These properties prevent users from hiding, minimizing, editing, or exporting the control, or changing its <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.Part.ChromeState%2A> value.
However, users can close or delete an <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart> control instance.
Gets or sets the error message that is displayed in a Web page in place of a control that could not be successfully added to the page.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart.ErrorMessage%2A> property can be assigned a value by a developer, so that a custom error message is displayed at the point where the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart> control is inserted into a page.
A string that contains the text of the error message.
The default value is a culture-specific error message.
Encodes the string value of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart.ErrorMessage"></xref> property.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart.RenderContents%2A> method encodes the string assigned to the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart.ErrorMessage%2A> property to ensure that it renders properly, and to protect against script injection attacks.
An <xref href="System.Web.UI.HtmlTextWriter"></xref> that encodes the error message.
This method is added only to implement the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ITrackingPersonalizable"></xref> interface.
This method is added only to implement the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ITrackingPersonalizable"></xref> interface.

Implements the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ITrackingPersonalizable"></xref> interface and calls the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart.EndLoadPersonalization"></xref> method.
This method is added only to implement the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ITrackingPersonalizable"></xref> interface.
Gets a value that indicates whether the control tracks the status of its changes.
`true` if the Web Parts control is responsible for determining when the control is considered changed; otherwise, `false`.
